articles.title: SEPTEMBER 1989
articles.summary: This document presents a detailed schedule of astronomical events for September and early October 1989, likely organized by an astronomy club (implied SJAA). It lists numerous star parties at various locations like Grant Ranch, Branham Lane, Fremont Peak, and Henry Coe State Park, often including astronomical twilight and moon phase details. Additionally, the schedule features a swap meet, a slide and equipment night, board meetings, and sessions for an introductory observational astronomy class.

articles.title: BY: JOHN GLEASON & JIM VAN NULAND
articles.summary: The article announces several upcoming astronomy events, including a September swap meet and a series of public star parties by SJAA at Branham Lane Park, for which volunteers are needed. It clarifies guidelines for private star parties at Grant Ranch, Henry Coe, and Fremont Peak, noting specific access rules and fees. Additionally, it provides updates on Lick Observatory's public program being booked for 1989 and the availability of lunar samples for certified educators.

articles.title: ANOTHER NEAR MISS
articles.summary: On August 24th, the fast-moving Apollo asteroid 1989 PB passed within 2.5 million miles of Earth, an event discovered by Eleanor Helin on August 3rd using the Palomar 18-inch Schmidt camera. This close approach ranks among the 10 nearest by any asteroid or comet ever recorded.

articles.title: NEW MOONS FOR NEPTUNE
articles.summary: Scientists at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory have announced the discovery of three new moons (1989 N2, N3, N4) orbiting Neptune, identified from Voyager 2 images. These moons possess nearly circular orbits close to the planet, with specified distances, orbital periods, and estimated diameters. Their presence near Neptune's ring arcs suggests a fragmentary ring system, and astronomers anticipate more discoveries during Voyager 2's upcoming historic flyby in late August.

articles.title: AND SPEAKING OF PLANETS......JUPITER
articles.summary: Jupiter observing season is underway, with the planet displaying unusual activity in its southern hemisphere. Recent observations indicate significant changes, including the movement of the Great Red Spot, the cessation of white spot activity, and a severe fading of the South Equatorial Belt (SEB), which now appears as two thin bands. These signs are interpreted by experts as precursors to a long-overdue South Equatorial Belt disturbance, a phenomenon not observed since 1978, prompting a call for amateur astronomers to monitor the giant planet.

articles.title: ASTRO ADS
articles.summary: The 'ASTRO ADS' section offers free classifieds for non-commercial astronomical products and services, providing submission guidelines and an example for a telescope sale. The document also details NASA's educational programs, including lunar sample disks for certified science teachers to use in classrooms and traveling displays of encapsulated lunar samples available for loan to museums and planetariums.

articles.title: FOR SALE: 4" f/30 professional solar prominence telescope. Missing Ha filter.
articles.summary: This document is a collection of classified advertisements from 1989, offering a wide array of used astronomical equipment for sale. Items include various telescopes such as refractors, Newtonians, and Schmidt-Cassegrains from brands like Celestron and Meade, as well as numerous accessories like eyepieces, mounts, filters, and astrophotography gear. Each listing provides a description, price, and contact information for the seller.

articles.title: SEPTEMBER STARRY NIGHTS BY: RICHARD STANTON
articles.summary: The article "SEPTEMBER STARRY NIGHTS" by Richard Stanton outlines the astronomical events for September, specifically noting that it will be a quiet month for meteor enthusiasts. While several minor meteor showers are expected to reach their maximum, many are very faint or potentially extinct, contrasting with the brighter Perseids observed the previous month.

articles.title: METEOR SHOWER SUMMARY
articles.summary: This document provides a summary of celestial events for September, listing several minor meteor showers such as the Delta Piscids, South Piscids, and Kappa Aquarids, all occurring throughout the month. Additionally, it highlights September as a good period for observing asteroids, offering a list of four brighter ones convenient for viewing.

articles.title: SEPTEMBER ASTEROIDS
articles.summary: This article provides ephemeris data for several asteroids (Pallas, Vesta, Eunomia, Victoria) for September, detailing their RA, DEC, and magnitude. It also announces the date and time of the Autumnal Equinox and presents a challenging deep-sky observing target: the Cocoon Nebula (IC 5146) in Cygnus, recommending specific equipment and conditions.

articles.title: BY: PATRICK M. DONNELLY
articles.summary: Patrick M. Donnelly begins an annual contemplation of "multiple stars of summer," defining them as close associations of four or more stars. These systems can be either truly gravitationally bound or optical groupings. The author plans to identify and describe approximately ten particularly notable multiple star systems.

articles.title: Summer Multiple Stars Observing Guide
articles.summary: This article provides an observing guide for multiple star systems visible during the summer, highlighting ten key targets across constellations like Lyra, Cygnus, Lacerta, Scorpius, Sagittarius, and Capricornus. It offers detailed descriptions for each system, including component counts, required telescope sizes, magnitudes, and tips for locating them. The guide emphasizes the beauty and challenge of observing these complex stellar arrangements.

articles.title: SPACE PROGRAM UPDATE
articles.summary: The article provides an update on space activities, detailing Voyager 2's new discoveries at Neptune, including ring arcs, four new moons, and a large atmospheric storm. It also reports on the Space Shuttle Columbia's successful return to flight for a classified Department of Defense mission, restoring the shuttle fleet to three orbiters, with Atlantis scheduled to launch the Galileo spacecraft to Jupiter in October. Furthermore, a congressional report calls for the construction of a fifth orbiter.

articles.title: LONG TERM SPACE GOALS SET BY PRESIDENT BUSH
articles.summary: President Bush announced ambitious long-term space goals on the 20th anniversary of Apollo 11, including establishing a Moon base by the early 21st century and a manned mission to Mars around 2016, alongside completing the space station by 1999. The plan will be reviewed by the National Space Council, while separate recommendations urge starting a replacement space shuttle immediately due to high risks of another shuttle loss before the space station's completion.

articles.title: GALILEO BEING READIED FOR LAUNCH TO JUPITER
articles.summary: The Galileo satellite is being prepared for an October launch aboard the Space Shuttle Atlantis. Its mission involves orbiting Jupiter and deploying a probe into its atmosphere. NASA expects protests at the launch due to Galileo's use of Radioisotope Thermoelectric Generators (RTGs) for power, a technology previously utilized in numerous space missions.

articles.title: FIRST TITAN 4 BOOSTER LAUNCHED SUCCESSFULLY
articles.summary: The new Titan 4 booster successfully completed its inaugural launch on June 14th. Designed to offer the same unmanned payload capacity as the Space Shuttle, its introduction casts doubt on the future use of the Vandenberg AFB shuttle pad. NASA has tentatively scheduled the Comet Rendezvous Asteroid Flyby spacecraft for a 1995 launch on the Titan 4, pending budget approval.

articles.title: FIRST PEGASUS LAUNCH SCHEDULED FOR AUGUST
articles.summary: The article announces the imminent first launch of the Pegasus small booster in August, detailing its unique air-launch capability from 40,000 ft for placing 600-1000 lb satellites into orbit. Additionally, it features a "Celestial Calendar" for September 1989, providing detailed information on lunar phases, positions and magnitudes of nearer planets (Mercury, Venus, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn), astronomical twilight times, and sidereal time, all in Pacific Daylight Time.

articles.title: DEPARTMENT OF PARKS AND RECREATION
articles.summary: The Department of Parks and Recreation's Gavilan District, specifically Fremont Peak State Park, has established new policies for amateur astronomers. Due to crowded conditions, a limit of five telescopes is set for the Observatory, with other setups directed to the paved area by the shop or the Coulter Group area. These sites are first-come, first-serve, require early setup, and mandate staying for the entire viewing period.

articles.title: GENERAL MEETINGS
articles.summary: The SJAA hosts monthly General Meetings at the Red Cross building in Los Gatos, California, featuring guest speakers on diverse astronomical topics and "Indoor Star Parties" for members to share interests. These meetings, held on the 1st Saturday of each month, welcome individuals with various passions including astrophotography, deep sky observation, and telescope making. Detailed directions and timings for the 8 PM start are provided.

articles.title: INDOOR STAR PARTIES
articles.summary: Indoor Star Parties are informal Saturday evening gatherings for amateur astronomers to socialize, discuss astronomy, and share equipment. Activities typically include outdoor telescope viewing or indoor presentations of astrophotography, sometimes alongside SJAA Board meetings and introductory astronomy workshops.

articles.title: FIELD EXPEDITIONS
articles.summary: The SJAA organizes "Star Parties" for astronomical observation on Saturdays near the New Moon. These events vary in location, from sites near San Jose to as far as Yosemite National Park, with specific details announced in the EPHEMERIS.

articles.title: FREMONT PEAK STATE PARK
articles.summary: Fremont Peak State Park is a highly popular observing location for Bay Area amateur astronomers, situated 70 miles south of San Jose. Rising nearly 3000 feet, it hosts significant deep sky observing and astrophotography sessions during New Moon weekends, often attracting 50-100 telescopes in summer months. The San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) utilizes Coulter Camp within the park and encourages members to participate in activities there.

articles.title: SAN JOSE ASTRONOMICAL ASSOCIATION MEMBERSHIP APPLICATION
articles.summary: This document is a membership application form for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA), outlining different membership options like 'Membership only,' 'Membership/S&T,' and 'Junior (Under 18)' with corresponding fees. It provides instructions for submitting the form and making checks payable to 'SJAA,' along with the treasurer's mailing address and contact number. The document also includes postal information indicating it's from a non-profit organization.
